Award.AwardTitle: TWC: Small: Collaborative: Multipath TCP Side Channel Vulnerabilities and Defenses

Directorate.LongName: Direct For Computer & Info Scie & Enginr

Division.LongName: Division Of Computer and Network Systems

Award.AbstractNarration:
The objective of this project is to understand and strengthen the security of Multipath TCP (MPTCP) - an IETF standardized suite of TCP extensions that allow one MPTCP connection, consisting of multiple sub-connections between two hosts, to use multiple paths simultaneously. Even though MPTCP has been gaining momentum in being widely deployed, its security is yet to be well understood. The project is expected to raise awareness of MPTCP security and ultimately yield a foundation for MPTCP security. The study will further increase the acceptance of MPTCP as an efficient, trustworthy, and next-generation transport layer protocol, especially considering that the deployment of new protocols can always be hindered by security concerns. The results will lead to development of guidelines and specifications for MPTCP through standards organizations such as IETF.

This project aims to gain an in-depth understanding of the implicit interaction among sub-connections within an MPTCP connection, the information that can be leaked or inferred through side channels by eavesdropping such interaction, and the potential attacks on MPTCP by exploiting such leaked or inferred information. The key insight is that the current MPTCP design inherently allows an attacker eavesdropping on one path to learn information (e.g., throughput) about the sub-connections along other paths. Such seemingly benign information leakage allows an attacker to hijack the entire MPTCP connection. This project considers three general threat models: on-path only attacker, host-assisted off-path attacker, and host-assisted on-path attacker. Based on these threat models, the PIs propose to study traffic offloading/onloading and sequence number inference attacks. The PIs also plan to design and validate countermeasures and defense mechanisms for MPTCP against such threats.

POR.DRECONTENT:
This project entitled ?TWC: Small: Collaborative: Multipath TCP Side Channel Vulnerabilities and Defenses? helped PI Shafiq to conduct research on finding and defending against side channel security vulnerabilities in multipath TCP as well as leveraging it to defend against website fingerprinting and censorship attacks. The award helped recruit and support graduate students (Farooqi, Mazhar, Zhou) to conduct research on this topic.

The PI and students accomplished the proposed goals of the project by systematically investigating a wide range of possible side channel attacks on multipath TCP.

The team found two vulnerabilities in multipath TCP. First, an attacker eavesdropping one multipath TCP subflow can infer the throughput of other multipath TCP subflows by analyzing the local and global sequence numbers (GSN) embedded in multipath TCP headers. Second, an attacker can send forged packets with the multipath TCP MP_PRIO option containing the backup flag to set any multipath TCP subflow as the backup, causing it to be stalled completely.

These vulnerabilities allow two practical attacks: directed traffic diversion attacks and hijack attacks. The team showed that an attacker can onload or offload controlled amount of traffic on specific multipath TCP subflows. We also show that an attacker controlling one path can force all traffic to route through itself by setting all other subflows as backup. We implemented and validated these attacks using multipath TCP Linux Kernel implementation.

In addition to publishing our findings in academic venues, the team engaged with the open-source community, in particular the IETF working group on multipath TCP. The collaboration with the IETF working group resulted in fixing the reported vulnerabilities based on our proposed solutions, including updates to the RFC 6824. See http://www.tessares.net/july-2017

The team also studied extensions of multipath TCP as defense mechanisms against website fingerprinting and censorship attacks. We are in the process of documenting our findings and preparing them for peer-review.
